Can you explain the concept of context switching in the Linux process scheduling? Assume that Linux makes the context switch instantaneous where the CPU context is saved by previously running process.
As stated in this presentation :
Context switching is the process of saving the context of a running process so it can return to it when given. In most organizations, context switching is typically a performance problem. Linux multitasking allows a single thread of execution to be split between running and context switched into another execution. This dissimilar context switch is called a time slice. Thread switching, on the other hand, is the operation that starts a different process in the context of the previously running process. Frogs and all other living tetrapods have a rod @-@ like bone called the stapes that aids in hearing by transferring vibrations from the ear drum — or homologous tympanum — to the inner ear. Temnospondyls also have a stapes, which projects into the otic cavity. The stapes likely evolved from the hyomandibula of lobe @-@ finned fishes. The positioning of the stapes and the shape of the otic region suggests that the tympani of temnospondyls and frogs are homologous, but the tympani of these two groups probably perform very different functions : Temnospondyls'tympana, despite being lined by equally delicate skin e @-@ to that of frogs, were large and constituted one of several supports for their relatively weak inner ears ( Cheek et al. 1956 ). The most basal group of temnospondyls is the superfamily Edopoidea. Edopoids have several primitive or plesiomorphic features, including a single occipital condyle and a bone called the intertemporal that is absent in other temnospondyls. Edopoids include the Late Carboniferous genus Edops and the family Cochleosauridae. Dendrerpetontidae has also been included in Edopoidea, and is the oldest known temnospondyl family. Balanerpeton woodi is the oldest species, having been present over 330 million years ago during the Pennsylvanian period. The skull and jaws of Dendrerpeton show normal temnospondyl features, but the arrangement of their vertebrae appears unusual. Some characteristics are not found in modern animals, and may imply that they were an aquatic, filter - feeder. Dendrerpeton was a small amphibian, usually measuring no more than 7.5 inches (18.5 cm) long, though it may have taken a small fish as a prey. Originally, temnospondyls were classified according to the structure of their vertebrae. Early forms, with complex vertebrae consisting of a number of separate elements, were placed in the suborder Rachitomi, and large Triassic aquatic forms with simpler vertebrae were placed in the suborder Stereospondyli. With the recent growth of phylogenetics, this classification is no longer viable. The basic rhachitomous condition is found in many primitive tetrapods, and is not unique to one group of temnospondyls. Moreover, the distinction between rhachitomous and stereospondylous forms is not as useful a technique as one might expect. Since archosaurs share the stereospondylous condition with most othergroupId, it is clear then that the common ancestor to all these groups had more or similar basic vertebrae than the modern forms, and left to diverge. The Stereospondyli did not include all of the large basal-amniote mainstem forms, and included many strange, giant forms such as meisterans and melanorion. As a result of these strange forms, the Stereospondyli were often called " transitional " forms to the amniotes. What will
